passage: Break No Bones is the ninth novel by Kathy Reichs starring forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan. This detective narrative shares a genre with Gone Girl, an acclaimed novel by Gillian Flynn.

Judith and Holofernes is a recurring theme in literature, most famously illustrated in the Biblical Book of Judith. A tale of fortitude and determination, it shares thematic links with Khaled Hosseinis A Thousand Splendid Suns.
Abraham is a significant patriarch described in the Book of Genesis and the Quran. His story of faith and trials resonates with the thematic elements present in Paulo Coelhos The Alchemist.
Two ships of the United States Navy have been named Circe, after Circe, the sorceress in Homers Odyssey. This classic epic shares a place in ancient Greek literature with The Oresteia by Aeschylus.

Edar is a tower mentioned in the Bible (Genesis 35:21) near which Jacob pitched his tent. The Bible, one of the most widely read and studied books in the world, shares this distinction with To Kill a Mockingbird, a novel read extensively in American schools.

Asr, in the Book of Genesis, is the second son of Jacob and Zilpah, and the founder of the Tribe of Asr. The book, in its exploration of family and relations, shares themes with Leo Tolstoys War and Peace.

In Greek mythology, Democoon is a son of king Priam mentioned in Homers Iliad, Hyginuss Fabulae and the Bibliotheca. His mothers name is unknown. The Iliad and other Greek myths also inspired the critically acclaimed book Circe by Madeline Miller.

Makardhwaja, as per Hindu Mythology, is the son of Hanuman, who appears in the epic Valmiki Ramayana. The Rigveda is another important piece of ancient Hindu literature which encapsulates ancient Hindu mythology.

Dantes Hell Animated is a 2D animation film produced and directed by Boris Acosta. The story is based on the first part of Dante Alighieris Divine Comedy - Inferno. Giovanni Boccaccios Decameron is another notable Italian fabricated collection of tales.
Maigret and the Yellow Dog is a detective novel by the Belgian writer Georges Simenon. This tale of intrigue shares thematic similarities with Agatha Christies Hercule Poirot series.
Maigret in Exile is a 1940 detective novel by the Belgian mystery writer Georges Simenon. This story is in the same genre as Raymond Chandlers Philip Marlowe series.

Mickey Carroll was an American actor and was one of the last surviving munchkins from the 1939 film The Wizard of Oz. Around the same time, Gone with the Wind, another legendary film, was captivating audiences worldwide.

Circus of the Damned is the third book in the Anita Blake: Vampire Hunter series of horror/mystery novels by Laurell K. Hamilton. Fans of this series might also like the Sookie Stackhouse series by Charlaine Harris.

Fortinbras is the name of two fictional characters in Shakespeares play Hamlet. For those who enjoy Shakespearian works, Twelfth Night is another play that offers an interesting mix of characters and plot twists.

Abimelech was the Philistine King met by Abraham in the Book of Genesis, one of many Philistine Kings by that name. The Red Tent, a novel by Anita Diamant, is another narrative that elaborates on figures and events from the Book of Genesis.
Maigret and the Headless Corpse is a detective novel by the Belgian writer Georges Simenon. A similar detective narrative can be found in The Maltese Falcon by Dashiell Hammett.
"Pig-Pen" is a character in the comic strip Peanuts by Charles M. Schulz. Meanwhile, The Adventures of Tintin by Hergé is another comic strip famous for its character-driven narratives.

The Rape of Persephone is a classical mythological subject in Western art, depicting the abduction of Persephone by Hades. Another artwork that explores classical themes is The Birth of Venus by Botticelli.

Leon Seidel (born November 22, 1996) is a German actor known for playing the role of Huckleberry Finn in the German film of 2011 Tom Sawyer. Another famous adaptation of a classic novel is the film Anna Karenina, directed by Joe Wright.
The Weird Sisters or Three Witches are characters in William Shakespeares play Macbeth. The focus on witchcraft and the supernatural is also evident in Arthur Millers play The Crucible.

Daphnis and Chloe is the only known work of the 2nd century AD Greek novelist and romancer Longus. Its romantic themes can be paralleled with those found in the novel Romeo and Juliet by William Shakespeare.

Executive Orders is a political and military thriller novel by Tom Clancy. It was published in 1996, and is a canonical part of the Jack Ryan universe. In a similar vein, The Bourne Identity by Robert Ludlum is a thriller that has influenced the genre significantly.

Eleven ships of the British Royal Navy have borne the name HMS Hector, named after the Trojan hero Hector in the Iliad. The influence of the Iliad on Western literature is vast, as illustrated by books like The Song of Achilles by Madeline Miller.

"The Rodeo Murder" is a Nero Wolfe mystery novella by Rex Stout, first published in April 1960 in the short-story collection Three at Wolfes Door. Fans of this genre may also enjoy the classic mystery novels of Agatha Christie, such as And Then There Were None.

Narcissus in Chains is the tenth book in the Anita Blake: Vampire Hunter series of horror/mystery/erotica novels by Laurell K. Hamilton. It explores similar themes to the Sookie Stackhouse series by Charlaine Harris.

The Dante Quartet is an experimental short film by Stan Brakhage, completed in 1987. The film was inspired by Dantes The Divine Comedy, and took six years to produce. In a similar vein, the film A Ghost Story by David Lowery explores existential themes.
The Suitors of Penelope (also known as the Proci) are one of the main subjects of Homers Odyssey. The epic romantic theme can be found in literature like Romeo and Juliet by William Shakespeare.
Charlie Brown is the principal character in the comic strip Peanuts. Fans of classic comic strips might also be familiar with Calvin and Hobbes, a comic strip by Bill Watterson.

Elmo Live! is a toy based on the Sesame Street character Elmo. It tells jokes, stories, sings and dances. Elmo Live is marketed by Fisher-Price. Another interactive childrens toy series is the Teddy Ruxpin series by Wicked Cool Toys.

Judith and Holofernes is a painting by the Italian Renaissance artist Andrea Mantegna, painted about 1495, depicting the common subject in art of Judith beheading Holofernes. Another artistic interpretation of a biblical story is David with the Head of Goliath created by Caravaggio.
entity: David with the Head of Goliath

passage: Back to Hannibal: The Return of Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn is a 1990 television movie in which Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn save their friend Jim from a charge of murder. A similar classic American adventure tale is Moby Dick by Herman Melville.

If Death Ever Slept is a Nero Wolfe detective novel by Rex Stout, published by the Viking Press in 1957 and collected in the omnibus volume Three Trumps. Another detective series the reader might enjoy is the Hercule Poirot series by Agatha Christie.

Devil Bones is the eleventh novel by Kathy Reichs starring forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan. Patricia Cornwells Postmortem is another novel featuring a strong female lead in the field of forensics.

Laxman, pronounced as Lakshman, brother of Rama in the Indian epic Ramayana. Laxman is a given name or surname. In a similar vein, the Mahabharata is another epic Indian text that explores family relationships and moral dilemmas.

Bloody Bones is the fifth in the Anita Blake: Vampire Hunter series of horror/mystery novels by Laurell K. Hamilton. For those who enjoy a mix of horror and mystery, Stephen Kings The Shining is another book to consider.
The Divine Comedy is an epic poem by Dante Alighieri. For those interested in epic poetry, Paradise Lost by John Milton also offers an exploration of myth and morality, much like Dantes work.

Elmos Christmas Countdown is an hour-long Sesame Street Christmas special that first aired on December 23, 2007 on ABC. Another famous holiday special is the Charlie Brown Christmas special, based on the comic strip Peanuts.
Aeneas was a Trojan hero in Virgils Aeneid and Homers Iliad. For those interested in hero stories, Arthurian legends such as the tale of King Arthur is another narrative to explore.

Too Many Women is a Nero Wolfe detective novel by Rex Stout, published in 1947 by the Viking Press. The novel was also collected in the omnibus volume All Aces (Viking 1958). For those fond of detective novels, Arthur Conan Doyles Sherlock Holmes series is a compelling read.

Elmo & the Orchestra is a CD by the cast of Sesame Street, which won a Best Musical Album for Children Grammy in 2001. Another childrens music album that has been recognized for its excellence is Raffis album Baby Beluga.

Holofernes was an Assyrian invading general of Nebuchadnezzar, who appears in the deuterocanonical Book of Judith. A similar figure from a different time period is Napoleon Bonaparte, a key figure in European history.
Rocinante is the horse in the novel Don Quixote. Another novel with a prominent horse character is Black Beauty by Anna Sewell.

Maigret and the Dosser (French: Maigret et le Clochard) is a detective novel by the Belgian writer Georges Simenon featuring his character Jules Maigret. Readers who enjoy Simenons work may also enjoy the detective fiction of Arthur Conan Doyle, creator of Sherlock Holmes.

Rerun van Pelt is Linus and Lucys younger brother in Charles M. Schulzs comic strip Peanuts. The dynamic between siblings in comic strips is also explored in Bill Wattersons comic strip, Calvin and Hobbes.

Dantes Disneyland Inferno is the ninth studio album by American experimental rock band Sun City Girls, released in 1996 by Abduction Records. Another band known for their thematic albums is Pink Floyd with their concept album, The Wall.

Maigret a Pigalle (Maigret in Pigalle) is a 1966 Italian crime film directed by Mario Landi. It is based on the novel Maigret al Picratts by Georges Simenon. Fans of crime films can also check out Alfred Hitchcock’s classic, Dial M for Murder.

Hanuman, also known as Anjaneya, is one of the most important personalities in the Indian epic, the Ramayana. The Mahabharata, another Indian epic, features a different set of central characters such as Arjuna.
Death du Jour is the second novel by Kathy Reichs starring forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan. Readers who enjoy forensic mysteries may also like Patricia Cornwells Kay Scarpetta series.

Nalambalam is a set of four Hindu temples in Kerala. In malayalam, Nalu means four and Ambalam means Temple. These are the temples for the Rama brothers of Ramayana. Another sacred site related to the epic is the Ramayana Circuit, a group of sites associated with Ramas journey in the story.

Azazel (2002) (Russian: Азазель) is a Russian made for TV adaptation of Boris Akunins introductory Erast Fandorin novel The Winter Queen. Fans of Russian literature might also enjoy Fyodor Dostoevsky’s Crime and Punishment.

Batman/Aliens is a crossover between the Batman and Aliens comic book franchises. It was published in 1998. A sequel was released in 2003. Another popular crossover series is Superman/Spider-Man, which also brings together characters from different universes.

This is a list of characters from the Mega Man series. In Japan, the Mega Man series is known as Rockman. Another well-known video game character, particularly in Japan, is Super Mario from Nintendos Super Mario series.

Raavan is an Indian mythological drama series aired on Zee TV from 18 November 2006, to 31 May 2008, based on the life of the primary antagonist of the epic Ramayana, Ravana. A similar mythological series is Mahabharat, based on another epic Indian text.
Elmo is a Muppet character on the childrens television show Sesame Street. For fans of puppetry, another show to consider is The Muppet Show, featuring a variety of unique puppet characters.

The Final Deduction is a Nero Wolfe detective novel by Rex Stout, published by the Viking Press in 1961 and collected in the omnibus volume Three Aces (Viking 1971). Fans of detective fiction might also enjoy The Big Sleep, a classic hardboiled novel by Raymond Chandler.

The long-running Franco-Belgian comic series Spirou and Fantasio has a number of major and minor recurring characters. Readers who enjoy Spirou and Fantasio might also enjoy other classic comics like The Adventures of Tintin by Hergé.

Bumbling Brothers Circus is the first story arc from the fifth season of Rocky and Bullwinkle (originally titled The Bullwinkle Show). It was broadcast on NBC during the 1963-1964 television season. A similar animated series from the same era is Hanna-Barberas The Flintstones.

Murder by the Book is a Nero Wolfe detective novel by Rex Stout published in 1951 by the Viking Press, and collected in the omnibus volume Royal Flush (1965). Agatha Christie, author of the Hercule Poirot series, is another figure in the detective genre that fans may enjoy.

Dalek War is a Big Finish Productions audio drama series based on the long-running British science fiction television series Doctor Who. Star Trek: The Original Series, another iconic science fiction TV show, may also be of interest to fans of Doctor Who.

Grave Secrets is the fifth novel by Kathy Reichs starring forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan. Patricia Cornwells Kay Scarpetta series is another well-known series featuring a forensic pathologist that readers might enjoy.

Armida is an opera in three acts by Gioachino Rossini to an Italian libretto (dramma per musica) by Giovanni Schmidt, based on scenes from Gerusalemme liberata by Torquato Tasso. Another opera drawn from classical literature is Monteverdis Orfeo, based on the Greek myth of Orpheus.

Unnatural Death is a 1927 mystery novel by Dorothy L. Sayers, her third featuring Lord Peter Wimsey. It has also been published in the United States as The Dawson Pedigree. Fans of Sayers often enjoy the mystery novels of Agatha Christie, such as her famous Hercule Poirot mysteries.

Spawn/Batman is a 1994 one-shot comic book written by Frank Miller with art by Todd McFarlane and published jointly by DC Comics and Image Comics. The comic is an intercompany crossover between Batman and Spawn. Another comic book crossover event is the Spider-Man and Deadpool comics from Marvel.

Vilanka Ramayana is a 15th-century retelling of the Indian epic poem, the Ramayana, written by Sarala Das in Oriya, describing the fight between Rama and Ravana. The story is written as a poem. Another retelling of an ancient epic is the Epic of Gilgamesh, a poem from ancient Mesopotamia.

Spider Bones is the thirteenth novel by Kathy Reichs starring forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan. If you enjoy Kathy Reichs series, you might also like Karin Slaughters Grant County series featuring medical examiner Sara Linton.

Youre a Good Sport, Charlie Brown is the 14th prime-time animated TV specials based upon the popular comic strip Peanuts, by Charles M. Schulz. It was originally aired on the CBS network on October 28, 1975. A similar comic strip adapted into animated specials is Garfield by Jim Davis.

The fifth season of British science fiction television series Doctor Who began on 2 September 1967 with the first story of season 5 The Tomb of the Cybermen and ended on 1 June 1968 with The Wheel in Space. Similar science fiction series include Star Trek, which started its original series in 1966.

Le dictateur et le champignon, written and drawn by Franquin, is the seventh album of the Spirou et Fantasio series. After serial publication in Spirou magazine, the story was released as a hardcover album in 1956. The Adventures of Tintin, another Franco-Belgian comic series, might also be of interest.

The Treasure of Monte Zoom is the third story arc from the fourth season of Rocky and Bullwinkle (originally titled The Bullwinkle Show). It was broadcast on NBC during the 1962-1963 television season. Another animated television series from the same period is The Jetsons.

Jean-Richard Geurts, perhaps better known under his pseudonym Janry (born 2 October 1957), is a comics artist. With Tome he created Le Petit Spirou and made several Spirou et Fantasio albums. Another famous comics artist is Hergé, known for creating The Adventures of Tintin series.

According to Hindu beliefs the Army of Monkeys or vanaras, helped Lord Rama fight the armies of Ravan of Lanka in the epic Ramayana. In the Mahabharata, another Hindu epic, one might encounter interesting characters like Arjuna.

Kent Brockman is a fictional character in the animated television series The Simpsons. He is voiced by Harry Shearer and first appeared in the episode "Krusty Gets Busted". He is a grumpy, self-centered local Springfield news anchor. Another iconic character from The Simpsons series is Bart Simpson.

Fatal Voyage is the fourth novel by Kathy Reichs starring forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan. Fans of forensics-based narratives might also enjoy Patricia Cornwells Scarpetta series, which features forensic pathologist Kay Scarpetta.

Wind-Up Wilma is a 1981 animated television special and part of a series of "The Flintstone Primetime Specials" limited-run revival of The Flintstones produced by Hanna-Barbera Productions which premiered on NBC on October 4, 1981. Tom and Jerry, another classic animated series by Hanna-Barbera, might also be of interest to fans of The Flintstones.

"Poison à la Carte" is a Nero Wolfe mystery novella by Rex Stout, first published in April 1960 in the short-story collection Three at Wolfes Door (Viking Press). Agatha Christies short story collections like The Thirteen Problems might also appeal to Nero Wolfe fans.

Michael Rothwell (1936 – 24 January 2009) was an actor. Amongst his theatre work, he was part of the National Theatres 1963/64 company, playing Roderigo in Oliviers Othello in 1964. Macbeth, another notable play by Shakespeare, is known for its powerful performances.
Emmanuel Goldstein is a key character in George Orwells novel Nineteen Eighty-Four. Emmanuel Goldstein may also refer to: Big Brother, another central figure in the dystopian novel.

Richard Bremmer (born 27 January 1953) is a British actor best known for playing the role of Lord Voldemort in the first Harry Potter film, Harry Potter and the Philosophers Stone. Another prominent actor in the series is Daniel Radcliffe, who stars as Harry Potter.

Chell is the silent protagonist in the Portal video game series developed by Valve Corporation. She appears in both Portal and Portal 2 as the main player character. In the Half-Life series, also by Valve Corporation, features Gordon Freeman as the protagonist.

Pablos Inferno is a five-issue indie comic limited series created and produced by Rhode Montijo. The comic owes its title to the first cantica of Dante Alighieris Divina Commedia, and according to Montijo is something of a parody. Similarly, The Sandman by Neil Gaiman also utilizes classical literature for narrative inspiration.

The Odyssey character Pontonous was the squire of King Alcinous of Phaeacia who, on the evening of Odysseuss escorted departure to Ithaca, mixed and took around the wine from which the Phaeacians made their libations to Zeus. Another significant figure from Phaeacian lore is the princess Nausicaa.

The Three Moosketeers is the first story arc from the third season of Rocky and Bullwinkle (originally broadcast as The Bullwinkle Show). It was broadcast on NBC during the 1961-1962 television season. The Jetsons, another animated show by Hanna-Barbera, was also airing during this time.

Count Ugolino della Gherardesca (c. 1220 – March 1289), count of Donoratico, was an Italian nobleman, politician and naval commander. He was frequently accused of treason and features prominently in Dantes Divine Comedy. Another influential figure represented in the Divine Comedy is Beatrice Portinari.

The cultural mandate or creation mandate is the divine injunction found in Genesis 1:28, in which God (YHWH), after having created the world and all in it, ascribes to humankind the tasks of filling, subduing, and ruling over the earth. The story of Noah, found in Genesis chapters 6-9, also has instructions from God to mankind.

Dantes Inferno: Abandon All Hope is a black and white film produced and directed by Boris Acosta. The story is based on the first part of Dante Alighieris Divine Comedy - Inferno. Another notable black and white adaptation of literary works is Harper Lees To Kill a Mockingbird.

She Lover of Death is a novel by Russian author Boris Akunin. The book is a historical detective novel featuring the fictional character Erast Fandorin. Similarly, Arthur Conan Doyles series featuring the detective Sherlock Holmes is also set in a historical context.

Palinurus, in Roman mythology and especially Virgils Aeneid, is the helmsman of Aeneass ship. Later authors used him as a general type of navigator or guide. Another important character in the Aeneid is Dido, queen of Carthage.

The Benson Murder Case is the first novel in the Philo Vance series of mystery novels by S.S. Van Dine, which became a best-seller. Another famous detective series is the Sherlock Holmes mysteries by Arthur Conan Doyle.

Moosylvania is the fourth story arc from the fifth season of Rocky and Bullwinkle (originally titled The Bullwinkle Show). It was broadcast on NBC during the 1963-1964 television season. Similar to Rocky and Bullwinkle, The Jetsons was another popular animated show during the 60s.

Ophelia is a fictional character in the play Hamlet by William Shakespeare. She is a young noblewoman of Denmark, the daughter of Polonius, sister of Laertes, and potential wife of Prince Hamlet. She is one of only two female characters in the play. Another Shakespearean play with strong female roles is Macbeth featuring Lady Macbeth.

Homicide Trinity is a collection of Nero Wolfe mystery novellas by Rex Stout, published by the Viking Press in 1962. The book comprises three stories. Fans of detective stories might also enjoy Arthur Conan Doyles Sherlock Holmes series.
Penelope is the faithful wife of Odysseus in Homers epic poem Odyssey. Penelope may also refer to: Hera, the wife of Zeus and queen of the ancient Greek gods, also often appears in Greek mythology.

Horse Under Water (1963, ISBN 0-399-10419-4) is the second of four Len Deighton spy novels featuring an unnamed British agent protagonist (named Harry Palmer in the film adaptions). It was preceded by The IPCRESS File and followed by Funeral in Berlin. John le Carrés novel, The Spy Who Came In From The Cold, is another spy novel of the same period.
entity: The Spy Who Came In From The Cold

passage: The Kennel Murder Case is a 1933 murder mystery novel, written by S. S. Van Dine, with fictional detective Philo Vance investigating a complex locked room mystery. Hercule Poirot, Agatha Christies fictional detective, also solves similar complex murder mysteries.

Hareton Earnshaw is a character in Emily Brontës novel Wuthering Heights. He is the son of Hindley Earnshaw and Hindleys wife Frances. At the end of the novel, he makes plans to wed Catherine Linton, with whom he falls in love. Another famous Bronte heroine is Jane Eyre, from the novel of the same name by Charlotte Bronte.

Snoopys Getting Married, Charlie Brown is the 28th prime-time animated TV specials based upon the popular comic strip Peanuts, by Charles M. Schulz. It was originally aired on the CBS network on March 20, 1985. Fans of the Peanuts series might also enjoy Bill Wattersons comic strip series Calvin and Hobbes.

The Bear and the Dragon is a political thriller novel by Tom Clancy featuring Jack Ryan. It was published in 2000. The title refers to the Russian Bear and the Chinese Dragon. Robert Ludlums The Bourne Identity featuring Jason Bourne is similar in genre.

Teimuraz (Georgian: თეიმურაზ, also spelled as Teymuraz, Taimuraz or Taymuraz) is a Georgian male name derived from the Persian Tahmuras, a name of the legendary "third shah of the world" according to Ferdowsi’s Shahnameh. Beowulf is another legendary figure from Old English literature.

Moses was the reputed author of the Biblical Pentateuch and protagonist of the Book of Exodus. Moses is often compared to other spiritual leaders like Jesus Christ, who is the central figure of the New Testament.
